articles.headline: Young Fliers See the Film, Be It PG or R
articles.snippet: Critics say airlines have relaxed their rules for in-flight movies, exposing children to violence and sexual content.
articles.abstract: Critics say airlines have relaxed their rules for in-flight movies, exposing children to violence and sexual content.
articles.lead_paragraph: A husband shoots his wife in the face, then drags her body from the pool of blood. A 12-year-old boy is crushed against a fence by a car. A teenager zips up her jeans in the bathroom after a sexual encounter.

articles.headline: Bush Plans a Limited Intervention on Mortgages
articles.snippet: President Bush announced several steps to help Americans who have credit problems meet the rising cost of their housing loans.
articles.abstract: President Bush announced several steps to help Americans who have credit problems meet the rising cost of their housing loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  Democrats praised President Bush’s proposals to help low-income homeowners on Friday but indicated they would continue to press measures opposed by the administration to expand the federal role in housing, making it likely that the issue will set off partisan battles this year and next.

articles.headline: Chief Says Fed Is Ready to Act on Credit Pinch
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke said the central bank “stands ready to take additional actions as needed” to prevent chaos in the mortgage markets from derailing the economy.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke said the central bank “stands ready to take additional actions as needed” to prevent chaos in the mortgage markets from derailing the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 31 — Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, declared on Friday that the central bank “stands ready to take additional actions as needed” to prevent the chaos in mortgage markets from derailing the broader economy.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Pay at Investment Banks Eclipses All Private Jobs
articles.snippet: Investment banking paid an average weekly wage of $8,367, compared with $841 for all private sector jobs.
articles.abstract: Investment banking paid an average weekly wage of $8,367, compared with $841 for all private sector jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Top money managers earn such huge incomes that even when their compensation is mixed with the much lower pay of clerks, secretaries and others, the average pay in investment banking is 10 times that of all private sector jobs, new government data shows.

articles.headline: Who Founded Facebook? A New Claim Emerges
articles.snippet: The Web site has been fighting claims that its founder stole the idea. Now another man says he was the creator.
articles.abstract: The Web site has been fighting claims that its founder stole the idea. Now another man says he was the creator.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 29 — Mark E. Zuckerberg is considered the founder of Facebook, the popular social networking Web site estimated to be worth upward of $1 billion.

articles.headline: When Bulls and Bears Act Unruly on a Seesaw
articles.snippet: In the past, wild swings in share prices, like those seen last month, have sometimes indicated that markets were turning in a different direction.
articles.abstract: In the past, wild swings in share prices, like those seen last month, have sometimes indicated that markets were turning in a different direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does it make sense for stock prices to plunge one day and soar the next, with little in the way of new information to explain either move?

articles.headline: Hey, Who’s He? With Gwyneth? The Google Guy
articles.snippet: One Google engineer has had his picture taken with more than 100 luminaries who have visited the company.
articles.abstract: One Google engineer has had his picture taken with more than 100 luminaries who have visited the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — The gallery of photos lining a hallway at Google’s headquarters here is filled with the faces of luminaries who have visited the company: Mikhail Gorbachev, Bill Clinton, the Dalai Lama, Muhammad Ali and Jane Fonda.

articles.headline: Hedge Funds and the Little People
articles.snippet: A court ruling expected in a Manhattan bankruptcy court could have significant implications for hedge funds domiciled in faraway places.
articles.abstract: A court ruling expected in a Manhattan bankruptcy court could have significant implications for hedge funds domiciled in faraway places.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURTON R. LIFLAND, a United States bankruptcy judge in Lower Manhattan, said last week that he needed more time to decide whether the liquidation of two failed Bear Stearns mortgage securities funds could proceed in the Cayman Islands, where they are incorporated, or in this country, where most of their assets and many of their investors reside.

articles.headline: Reeling In the College-Bound
articles.snippet: One in five student borrowers passes up a less expensive federal student loan in favor of private lenders, according to a recent study.
articles.abstract: One in five student borrowers passes up a less expensive federal student loan in favor of private lenders, according to a recent study.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newport, R.I.

articles.headline: West Bank Boys Dig a Living in Settler Trash
articles.snippet: In a sign of the dire economic conditions for Palestinians, a dump is now a lifeline for scavengers.
articles.abstract: In a sign of the dire economic conditions for Palestinians, a dump is now a lifeline for scavengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: AD DEIRAT, West Bank, Aug. 30 — As the truck unloads, the children pounce on the garbage like flies. Some swing aloft on the hydraulic pistons that open the back, then drop onto the mound of trash to grab a piece of metal, a crushed can, a soda bottle or a stinking T-shirt.

articles.headline: Afghan Police Suffer Setbacks as Taliban Adapt
articles.snippet: The Taliban have driven government forces out of roughly half of a key area that the U.S. and NATO had declared a success.
articles.abstract: The Taliban have driven government forces out of roughly half of a key area that the U.S. and NATO had declared a success.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan, Aug. 26 — Over the past six weeks, the Taliban have driven government forces out of roughly half of a strategic area in southern Afghanistan that American and NATO officials declared a success story last fall in their campaign to clear out insurgents and make way for development programs, Afghan officials say.

articles.headline: Can the Mortgage Crisis Swallow a Town?
articles.snippet: At current rates, analysts expect foreclosure filings to hit a rate approaching heights not seen since the Great Depression.
articles.abstract: At current rates, analysts expect foreclosure filings to hit a rate approaching heights not seen since the Great Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maple Heights, Ohio

articles.headline: Safety Agency Faces Scrutiny Amid Changes
articles.snippet: As imports create a greater oversight challenge, Bush appointees at the Consumer Product Safety Commission have voiced few objections.
articles.abstract: As imports create a greater oversight challenge, Bush appointees at the Consumer Product Safety Commission have voiced few objections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 — In March 2005, the Consumer Product Safety Commission called together the nation’s top safety experts to confront an alarming statistic: 44,000 children riding all terrain vehicles were injured the previous year, nearly 150 of them fatally.

articles.headline: Booked on AA Flight 1659? Better Take a Book
articles.snippet: More than 100 domestic commercial flights are officially late 70 percent or more of the time, an analysis found.
articles.abstract: More than 100 domestic commercial flights are officially late 70 percent or more of the time, an analysis found.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWARK, Aug. 29 — Passengers are understandably angry when they are stuck on a delayed flight. But they should not necessarily be surprised — especially those traveling on flights like American Airlines 1659, departing every afternoon from Newark Liberty International Airport to Chicago.

articles.headline: Chaos in Darfur Rises as Arabs Fight With Arabs
articles.snippet: Arab tribes accused of massacring civilians in Darfur are now turning their considerable firepower on one another.
articles.abstract: Arab tribes accused of massacring civilians in Darfur are now turning their considerable firepower on one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: NYALA, Sudan, Aug. 28 — Some of the same Arab tribes accused of massacring civilians in the Darfur region of Sudan are now unleashing their considerable firepower against one another in a battle over the spoils of war that is killing hundreds of people and displacing tens of thousands.

articles.headline: Few Expect a Panacea in a Rate Cut by the Fed
articles.snippet: Some policy makers caution that the central bank’s main tool to keep the economy from sliding into recession may be ill-suited to the problem it faces.
articles.abstract: Some policy makers caution that the central bank’s main tool to keep the economy from sliding into recession may be ill-suited to the problem it faces.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 — Would cheaper money relieve the anxiety in financial markets about shoddy mortgages and declining home prices?

articles.headline: As Labor Talks Near, Studios Play Down Numbers
articles.snippet: Hollywood had one of its best summers in recent history, but the studios are not quite popping the Champagne.
articles.abstract: Hollywood had one of its best summers in recent history, but the studios are not quite popping the Champagne.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hollywood had one of its best summers in recent history, crossing the $4 billion mark in ticket sales for the first time and stockpiling hits to release on DVD. But the movie studios are not quite popping the Champagne — at least publicly.

articles.headline: Software via the Internet: Microsoft in ‘Cloud’ Computing
articles.snippet: The company plans to make available free software that connects its Windows operating system to software services delivered on the Internet.
articles.abstract: The company plans to make available free software that connects its Windows operating system to software services delivered on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 — The empire is preparing to strike back — again.

articles.headline: On Two Fronts, One Nuclear, Iran Is Defiant
articles.snippet: Two announcements Sunday appeared intended to enforce Iran’s refusal to back down in the face of stepped-up pressure from the United States.
articles.abstract: Two announcements Sunday appeared intended to enforce Iran’s refusal to back down in the face of stepped-up pressure from the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN, Iran, Sept. 2 — Iran’s leaders issued dual, defiant statements on Sunday, with the president announcing that the nation had 3,000 active centrifuges to enrich uranium and the top ayatollah appointing a new Islamic Revolutionary Guards commander who once advocated military force against students.
articles.byline: By Michael Slackman and Nazila Fathi

articles.headline: Insurers Bear Brunt of Anger in New Orleans
articles.snippet: Insurance companies have become a new villain in the tales people tell about the slow recovery in Louisiana.
articles.abstract: Insurance companies have become a new villain in the tales people tell about the slow recovery in Louisiana.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Maxine Cassin, a prominent local poet, thought her homeowners insurance would be more than enough to cover the $100,000 of hurricane damage to her Uptown house here. But two years after Hurricane Katrina hit, Ms. Cassin and her husband, Joseph, are still stranded far from home; their insurer has offered them just $41,000.
articles.byline: By Leslie Eaton and Joseph B. Treaster

articles.headline: CBS Backs ‘Kid Nation’ Despite Outcry
articles.snippet: Network executives as well as the program’s producer continued to express confidence that the reality show would go on as planned.
articles.abstract: Network executives as well as the program’s producer continued to express confidence that the reality show would go on as planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a drumbeat of accusations directed toward its new reality series “Kid Nation,” CBS has shown no sign of backing away from plans to broadcast the show starting Sept. 19.
